channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SPR-5574] Autowiring should support ordered collection driven by Order annotation or Ordered interface
item.description:
Let suppose that there are beans of a given type T and these beans are marked by interface Ordered or annotation Order. It does make really sense to preserve their order according to Ordered/Order marker if they are collected. See following code for illustration.

@Component
@Order(value=1)
public class BusinessServiceA implements BusinessService{}

@Component
@Order(value=2)
public class BusinessServiceB implements BusinessService{}

@Component
public class ServiceRegistry {
@Autowired
public List<BusinessService> services;
}

assertThat(services.get(0).getClass(), is(BusinessServiceA.class));
assertThat(services.get(1).getClass(), is(BusinessServiceB.class));
item.summary: Autowiring should support ordered collection driven by Order annotation or Ordered interface

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Would love to see this implemented, have run into use cases needing this!!

Here is a version that I have implemented at the time I needed that feature in an ExtendedBeanFactory:

	@Override
 
	protected Object doResolveDependency(DependencyDescriptor descriptor,
 
			Class<?> type, String beanName, Set<String> autowiredBeanNames,
 
			TypeConverter typeConverter) throws BeansException {
 
		Object result = super.doResolveDependency(descriptor, type, beanName,
 
				autowiredBeanNames, typeConverter);
 
		if (result != null && descriptor.getField() != null) {
 
			if (descriptor.getField().isAnnotationPresent(OrderedWired.class)) {
 
				if (type.isArray()) {
 
					Object[] resultArray = (Object[]) result;
 
					if (log.isDebugEnabled()) {
 
						log.debug("Sorting results for {}.{}", descriptor
 
								.getField().getDeclaringClass(), descriptor
 
								.getDependencyName());
 
					}
 
					Arrays.sort(resultArray,
 
							AnnotationAwareOrderComparator.INSTANCE);
 
					return resultArray;
 
				} else if (List.class.isAssignableFrom(type)) {
 
					List<?> resultList = (List<?>) super.doResolveDependency(
 
							descriptor, type, beanName, autowiredBeanNames,
 
							typeConverter);
 
					if (log.isDebugEnabled()) {
 
						log.debug("Sorting results for {}.{}", descriptor
 
								.getField().getDeclaringClass(), descriptor
 
								.getDependencyName());
 
					}
 
					Collections.sort(resultList,
 
							AnnotationAwareOrderComparator.INSTANCE);
 
					return resultList;
 
				}
 
			}
 
		}
 
		return result;
 
	}

And this would be wired like this at the moment:

	@Autowired
 
	@OrderedWired
 
	private List<DataInitializer> dataInitializers;

Finally implemented as a core feature for 4.0: However, not in the BeanFactory's resolveDependency itself but rather in AutowiredAnnotationBeanPostProcessor, in order to limit its applicability to @Autowired/@Inject. Programmatic callers of resolveDependency can call AnnotationAwareOrderComparator.sortIfNecessary(...) as they see fit.

Juergen

@Juergen,
Any chance this will be backported to 3.2.x?

I'm afraid not, since 3.2.x is in maintenance mode already... with the upcoming 3.2.7 being the last planned release in that line, just fixing a few remaining bugs.

That said, is there anything preventing you from upgrading to the 4.0 line? The upcoming 4.0.1 fixes all known regressions from 3.2.x, so it should be a very smooth upgrade... as long as the minimal system requirements are met (see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/wiki/Migrating-from-earlier-versions-of-the-spring-framework).

Juergen

As this will not be backported i add here the steps i took to implement it in an ExtendedBeanFactory for 3.2 at the time. (Upgrading from Spring 3.2 to 4.0 was a breeze by the way! 1h of work. Thanks for that )

-> I removed the OrderedWired Annotation in this code, so arrays and collections are always sorted.

1. create ExtendedBeanFactory:

    public class ExtendedBeanFactory extends DefaultListableBeanFactory {
 
        private static final Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ExtendedBeanFactory.class);
 
 
 
        public ExtendedBeanFactory() {
 
            super();
 
        }
 
 
 
        public ExtendedBeanFactory(BeanFactory parentBeanFactory) {
 
            super(parentBeanFactory);
 
        }
 
 
 
        @Override
 
        protected Object doResolveDependency(DependencyDescriptor descriptor, Class<?> type, String beanName, Set<String> autowiredBeanNames, TypeConverter typeConverter) throws BeansException {
 
            Object result = super.doResolveDependency(descriptor, type, beanName, autowiredBeanNames, typeConverter);
 
            if (result != null) {
 
                if (type.isArray()) {
 
                    Object[] resultArray = (Object[]) result;
 
                    if (log.isDebugEnabled()) {
 
                        log.debug("Sorting results for {}.{}", descriptor.getField().getDeclaringClass(), //$NON-NLS-1$
 
                                descriptor.getDependencyName());
 
                    }
 
                    Arrays.sort(resultArray, AnnotationAwareOrderComparator.INSTANCE);
 
                    return resultArray;
 
                } else if (List.class.isAssignableFrom(type)) {
 
                    List<?> resultList = (List<?>) super.doResolveDependency(descriptor, type, beanName, autowiredBeanNames,
 
                            typeConverter);
 
                    if (log.isDebugEnabled()) {
 
                        log.debug("Sorting results for {}.{}", descriptor.getField().getDeclaringClass(), //$NON-NLS-1$
 
                                descriptor.getDependencyName());
 
                    }
 
                    Collections.sort(resultList, AnnotationAwareOrderComparator.INSTANCE);
 
                    return resultList;
 
                }
 
            }
 
            return result;
 
        }
 
    }

2. create ExtendedXmlWebApplicationContext:

    public class ExtendedXmlWebApplicationContext extends XmlWebApplicationContext {
 
 
 
        @Override
 
        protected DefaultListableBeanFactory createBeanFactory() {
 
            return new ExtendedBeanFactory(getInternalParentBeanFactory());
 
        }
 
 
 
    }

3. create ExtendedDispatcherServlet

    public class ExtendedDispatcherServlet extends DispatcherServlet {
 
 
 
        public ExtendedDispatcherServlet() {
 
            super();
 
            setContextClass(ExtendedXmlWebApplicationContext.class);
 
        }
 
 
 
        public ExtendedDispatcherServlet(WebApplicationContext webApplicationContext) {
 
            super(webApplicationContext);
 
            setContextClass(ExtendedXmlWebApplicationContext.class);
 
        }
 
 
 
    }

4. declare it in web.xml

    <context-param>
 
        <param-name>contextClass</param-name>
 
        <param-value>org.....ExtendedXmlWebApplicationContext</param-value>
 
    </context-param>
 
    <servlet>
 
        <servlet-name>appServlet</servlet-name>
 
        <servlet-class>org.....ExtendedDispatcherServlet</servlet-class>
 
    </servlet>

For test integration this was a bit more tricky as i needed to override the AbstractDelegatingSmartContextLoader. If this code is desired I can post this too.

As said, upgrading to 4.0 was a simple excercise, so if you can upgrade i would go for that solution.
Anybody using Spring WebFlow would be blocked from upgrading to Spring 4.0 until SWF 2.3.3, which includes SWF-1600, is released.

If I want to sort a list of beans of type A for example, I don't think it's enough to implement Ordered interface, I move to 4.0.0 but the getOrder method it's not call, I have to declare bean of type BeanPostProcessor in order to be call getOrder method from OrderComparator class.

I's normal this behavior ?

thanks
Sorin

Hi,

This issue has been closed. If you have a question, please raise it on StackOverflow with the #spring tag. What you are describing should work out-of-the box: both Ordered implementations and annotated class with @Order are used to order the collection to auto wire.

Thanks.
